title: Pulp Cavity Structure
content: The pulp cavity is divided into two parts: the pulp chamber (in the crown) and the root canal (in the root). Odontoblasts in the coronal pulp are cuboidal but become flatter toward the root apex. This internal structure plays a critical role in tooth vitality and sensitivity.

title: Pulp Horns and Their Significance
content: Pulp horns are projections of the pulp chamber corresponding to the cusps or lobes of the crown. They are more prominent in younger individuals and tend to regress with age due to secondary dentin formation.
reference: See Fig. 13.7 and Fig. 13.8B on p. 193

title: Size of Pulp Cavity and Age
content: In young individuals, the pulp cavity is large due to minimal dentin deposition. Over time, secondary dentin reduces the pulp chamber size, affecting restorative decisions.
reference: See Fig. 13.3A and B on p. 192

title: Apical Foramen and Development
content: Initially wide during development, the apical foramen becomes constricted upon root formation. Its position may vary, impacting endodontic procedures.

title: Accessory and Delta Canals
content: Some teeth may have lateral or accessory canals branching from the main root canal. A delta system refers to multiple tiny canals near the apex, complicating endodontic cleaning.
reference: See Fig. 13.5 and Fig. 13.6 on p. 194

title: Root Canal Curvatures and Variations
content: Canal curvature varies from straight to sharply curved, particularly in mesial roots. Some canals join before exiting at a common apical foramen, while others remain separate.

title: Radiographic Evaluation
content: Radiographs provide a two-dimensional view of three-dimensional pulp structures. Knowledge of internal anatomy helps interpret radiographs and identify accessory canals.

title: Clinical Implications in Endodontics
content: Accurate knowledge of pulp anatomy prevents procedural errors like perforations or missed canals. Variation in anatomy due to age, trauma, or race must be considered during treatment.

title: Tooth Fractures and Pulp Involvement
content: Fractures may involve the enamel, dentin, and pulp. Cusp fractures often follow developmental grooves and can lead to pulpitis.
reference: See Fig. 13.26 and Fig. 13.27 on p. 214

title: Mandibular Canal and Root Apex Relations
content: Understanding the proximity of mandibular root apices to the mandibular canal is essential in endodontics and surgery. Improper techniques may injure the mandibular nerve.
